title: Panel part layout error when double clicking sash to auto resize
body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start vscode with sidebar hidden
2. Open panel part
3. Double click panel part sash :bug:

```
  ERR Cannot read property 'height' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'height' of undefined
    at PanelPart.get preferredHeight [as preferredHeight] (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/workbench/browser/parts/panel/panelPart.js:67:37)
    at resizeToPreferredSize (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/browser/ui/grid/grid.js:338:102)
    at SerializableGrid.onDidSashReset (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/browser/ui/grid/grid.js:350:17)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:461:41)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:461:41)
    at e (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:70:138)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at i (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:43:93)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at e (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:70:138)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at i (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:43:93)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:461:41)
    at i (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:43:93)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at sash.onDidReset (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/browser/ui/splitview/splitview.js:484:42)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:458:38)
    at Sash.onMouseDoubleClick (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/browser/ui/sash/sash.js:203:30)
    at Emitter.fire (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/common/event.js:461:41)
    at HTMLDivElement.fn (file:///mnt/nvmefiles/vscode/out/vs/base/browser/event.js:9:35)
```

This check prevents the `dimension` to be initialized if the sidebar is not visible on startup which is needed to calculate the height for the panel
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/c617db19b08bfdae8e2c540470bf82dd405c3895/src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/sidebar/sidebarPart.ts#L192-L194

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/c617db19b08bfdae8e2c540470bf82dd405c3895/src/vs/workbench/browser/parts/panel/panelPart.ts#L62-L65

title: File resolution in "node_modules/.bin" should be relative to the module
body: Issue Type: Feature Request For an example, `yarn add nyc` and open `node_modules/.bin/nyc`. The relative requires do not link to the files that are required at runtime. Would need to know which module installed each bin. Probably by parsing all the package.json's in `node_modules`. After a quick glance, I see there is not a way to query yarn or npm for this information. VS Code version: Code 1.37.1 (f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35, 2019-08-15T16:16:34.800Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.7.0

title: Preserve the cursor-undo stack across edits

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
There is a command called `cursorUndo` ("Soft Undo"), which undo's cursor and selection movements.

**The undo stack for cursor undo's seems to be deleted after text edits are made.**

I request that the cursor undo stack will be saved in each text undo entry, and be loaded as the current cursor undo stack after undo/redo.

#### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Type <kbd>bar</kbd>
2. Press <kbd>Home</kbd>
3. Execute the `cursorUndo` command using <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>U</kbd>. the cursor will move back to *after* `bar`.
4. Press <kbd>Home</kbd> again
5. Type <kbd>foo</kbd>
6. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Z</kbd> to undo. `foo` should be deleted and the cursor should be *before* `bar`.
7. Execute the `cursorUndo` command again using <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>U</kbd>. Nothing happens.

**Desired behavior:** The cursor should move to *after* `bar`, just like it did before we made an edit and undo'd it.

#### System Info:

VSCode Version: 1.38.1
OS: Windows

#### Similar Issues:

I believe this is the intention of #45371, but I'm not sure. That issue is poorly worded and it is very unclear what the author intended. It is also very old and its author seems to not respond.

This is **NOT** the same as #34093, which is requesting that the undo stack and cursor undo stack be merged together into a single stack.

title: Terminal folders (unlike files) open new instance/window
body:
I use the feature in iterm2 to link from external builds into vscode for errors. It works fine for absolute paths to files - if I have a current workspace open containing this file, that one is focused.

However, with folder paths like the ones produced by my current webpack/marko build:

```
ERROR in ../web/src/marko/pages/admin/users.component.js
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'web/services/users' in '/Users/viktor/dev/projects/kb-frontend/packages/web/src/marko/pages/admin'
 @ ../web/src/marko/pages/admin/users.component.js 2:15-44
 @ ../web/src/marko/pages/admin/users.marko
 @ ../web/src/marko/index.marko
 @ ../web/src/marko/marko-bootstrap.js
 @ multi @babel/polyfill ../web/src/marko/marko-bootstrap ../web/src/materialize/kb-materialize.scss
```

If I click the absolute path to the folder, a new window of vscode is launched instead of my current workspace even though it is contained there.

My iterm2 settings look like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/116520/66259726-e5f9e580-e7b4-11e9-8741-f9b8d8d048c3.png)

It would be awesome if vscode could handle folders just like it handles files and putting me into my existing session instead of a new.

title: Rename "Soft Undo" to "Cursor Undo" in the Command Palette
body:
There is a **command called "cursorUndo"**, which undo's cursor and selection movements.
In the command palette it is called "Soft Undo".

I think the **name in the command palette should be changed from "Soft Undo" to "Cursor Undo"**.

#### Motivation:

This will make the command more discoverable, and more intuitive for users to figure out what it does.

When I found this command in the command palette, I tried typing "hello" and then using it, but it did nothing, because the cursor hasn't moved since the last edit.
I had to google it to figure out what the command does.

#### Reasoning:

Even though the command also undo's selection changes and not just cursor movements, I think "cursor" is a general term the refers to both "cursor" and "selection".

Also, the command name itself is already "cursorUndo", it makes sense for the name in the command palette to use the same term.

Having "cursor" in the command's name will make it clear it undo's things that the cursor does, such as moving and selecting text.
A user that will find this command in the command palette will most likely attempt to move the cursor and then use the command, and then will understand what it does.

#### System Info:

VSCode Version: 1.38.1
OS: Windows

title: Feature-Request: cursorRedo / Soft Redo

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
There is a command called "cursorUndo" (name in command palette: "Soft Undo") that undo's cursor and selection movements.

There should be a matching "cursorRedo" (name in command palette: "Soft Redo") to redo those movements after undoing with "cursorUndo".

VSCode Version: 1.38.1
OS: Windows

title: Hide "(Workspace)" and "[Administrator]" suffixes from the window title
body:
A tiny request.

- VSCode version: 1.38.1
- OS: Windows 10

Steps to reproduce:
1. Run VS Code as administrator 
2. Set the window title to "${rootName}"
3. Observe suffixes are added to the workspace name is the window title

While this suffixes are useful I would like an option to hide them to only display the workspace/folder name. Minimalist, clearer title when switching between several projects opened in VS Code. Plus those suffixes are of no use if VS Code is always launched as admin with always rootName as window title.

Actual window title:

title: we need a shortcut to escape/close the control palette selection (when auto-selection is activated)
body:
By pressing `ctrl`+`P` the command palette opens. If we keep pressing `ctrl`, we can move the selection down simply by pressing `P`. We only need to release `ctrl` to open the file. It's a great feature but once we are on it, it's difficult to escape (when I don't find the file I search, I often end up opening the random file that is currently selected). 

It's possible to escape the auto selection by pressing `esc` while pressing `ctrl`, but this combination of key isn't really easy.

 It would be much easier to escape the control palette using `shift` (or, even better, using a keyboard shortcut we could choose)

title: Webview: Cannot bypass self-signed certificate error
body:
Issue Type: Bug I am using [axios](https://github.com/axios/axios) to make `GET` requests to fetch some JSON data. This is code I'm using: ```js const config = { url: , headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ` } }; return axios(config).then((response) => { console.log(response); }).catch((error) => { console.log(error); }); ``` There are two scenarios that I'm testing this in: when the request is made in the extension code and when it is made in a webview. ### Extension Making the request above returns an error response (this is expected for the REST URL I'm using): ```json { "code": "DEPTH_ZERO_SELF_SIGNED_CERT", "isAxiosError": true, "message": "self signed certificate", ... } ``` To bypass this self-signed certificate error, I added `httpsAgent: new https.Agent({ rejectUnauthorized: false })` to the `config` object. After doing so, I get a response with the correct status code and the JSON data I expect. ```js const config = { url, headers: { Authorization: `Bearer ${token}` }, httpsAgent: new https.Agent({ rejectUnauthorized: false }) }; ``` ### Webview When I make the request with `httpsAgent` omitted from `config`, I see the following error in the webview developer tools. The issue is this: when I add in `httpsAgent: new https.Agent({ rejectUnauthorized: false })`, I **still** see the same error: ``` Failed to load resource: net::ERR_CERT_AUTHORITY_INVALID ``` --- VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:31:32.854Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.7.0

title: Add support for `git-crypt`
body:
This PR resolves #34330 by adding support for [git-crypt](https://github.com/AGWA/git-crypt/), a tool which encrypts and decrypts files as a git filter.

Currently VS Code does not properly show diffs for files that are encrypted on the `remote` but decrypted locally.

Here is some of the current behavior:

A file will have no changes (see below that `production.yaml` doesn't show up in the `git status` panel) but will show in the editor that the whole file was modified:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/549323/66243607-0002cd80-e6ba-11e9-94ad-d827f300813c.png)

We can see here when bringing up the inline diffs, that it's comparing the decrypted local file with the encrypted `HEAD` version:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/549323/66243651-2a548b00-e6ba-11e9-9a6c-e4a5a5bfeb2a.png)

Lastly, when the file is changed (shown below as showing up in the `git status` on the panel), and the `git diff` is opened, the diff isn't shown because the left side is the binary version:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/549323/66243697-67208200-e6ba-11e9-8d08-48fe61039ced.png)

This PR is fairly simple, and doesn't attempt to solve the total scope of adding generic support for any and all filters. However, I hope this can get accepted in the meantime before that solution is realized to support this specific issue.

This PR checks after a `git show` to see if the buffer contains a [magic word](https://github.com/AGWA/git-crypt/blob/master/commands.cpp#L460) that indicates it is a `git-crypt` encrypted blob. If it is, then it runs it into `git-crypt smudge` which will decrypt the contents appropriately. This resolves all of the cases mentioned above.

A potential implementation for solving the generic issue would be to read `.gitattributes` for the file being `git show`'d and see what the `filter` is and hand that as the program to execute the blob on. However, this would require significantly more testing which was out of scope for the work I'm doing.

title: Add git.showCommitInput config option (#79074)
body:
Adds feature requested in #79074.

To implement this, I mostly followed the pattern for the 'git.branchSortOrder' option and used VS Code's SourceControl API to toggle visibility of the input box.

title: VS Code's UI rendering freezes until I switch to any other app.
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.14.6 (18G87)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Not sure how to get into this state

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: I haven't tried it yet.

---

Basically what happens is VS Code's UI rendering gets entirely frozen (though it seems to still work behind the scenes, just not visible), until I press `cmd-tab` to switch to any other app.

As soon as I switch to another app, the rendering of VS Code (now not the focused window) jumps to where it should be.

When I switch back to VS Code, I can continue for a few seconds until the rendering freezes again.

VS Code is still operational in this state (except for rendering), because I can type sequences of keys, and knowing what to expect the edited text to be, I can switch to another app and come back, and see the expected text.

title: Support font transparency in minimap

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I don't know how feasible this is, but it would be great if the minimap used the same font transparency as the editor.

For instance:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222386-a9d06300-e696-11e9-9f52-71c0fd7fe474.png)
corresponds to 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222406-b48af800-e696-11e9-9c13-6f2821d6adf6.png)

It gets very confusing when you have a lot of comments.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15098499/66222541-029ffb80-e697-11e9-9b59-d96362a4a836.png)

I'm sure you can tell the bottom right block are comments. But did you know the top block also are?

Yes, I know, I could pick a color that more closely resembles the grey I'm after without using transparency. And that works out great. But from a theme creators perspective, not being able to use font transparency really cuts down on your ability to easily tweak things and make scalable systems of color.

title: VSCode won't launch on mac
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1 "b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0 x64"
- OS Version: MacOS 10.14.6 (18G103)

For the last couple weeks (I wish I could be more precise, although I know it first happened sometime within the last two months), my laptop gets into a state where it can no longer launch VSCode from the command line or app icon. This happens most days. There are three separate work arounds that I have found (listed below), however each of these only works temporarily, inevitably I end up in this broken state again.

Steps to Reproduce (icon):
1. Click on "Visual Studio Code" app icon
2. Nothing happens, no window appears, no dot appears by the icon
Steps to Reproduce (command line):
1. Run "code ." in some folder in my user directory
2. Nothing happens, no window appears, no dot appears by the icon

If I launch with "--verbose" I see:
```
~/mc/pxt(master=) $ code --verbose
[main 2019-10-04T15:38:02.271Z] Sending env to running instance...
[main 2019-10-04T15:38:02.277Z] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
[main 2019-10-04T15:38:02.277Z] Lifecycle#kill()
```
If I launch with "--verbose --disable-gpu" (which doesn't fix the issue) I see:
```
~/mc/pxt(dazuniga/docs_header *=) $ code --disable-gpu --verbose
[20394:1004/083920.476724:ERROR:gpu_process_transport_factory.cc(1017)] Lost UI shared context.
[main 2019-10-04T15:39:20.568Z] Sending env to running instance...
[main 2019-10-04T15:39:20.572Z] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
[main 2019-10-04T15:39:20.572Z] Lifecycle#kill()
```

Doing any of the following will **temporarily** fix the issue:
1. launch with the "--user-data-dir ~" command line option. VSCode will open fine. I'm not running vscode from any remote location or using sudo however.
2. Rebooting my laptop. When I reboot, vscode will launch again, but inevitably I get into this broken state again within a day or so.
3. If I search for "Electron" processes and kill them all:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6453828/66221703-71278e00-e684-11e9-87ef-a86ed61d3de7.png)
then vscode will launch again.
Edit: Actually, after kill these electron processes vscode will start but none of my keyboard strokes are making into the window. Keycords don't work and I can't type in buffers.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

The most recent time this happened is this morning. Last night my laptop died because it ran out of power, and I then charged it over night and opened it this morning. As MacOS does, it restored all the windows and processes I had running before it died from low-power. There were likely vscode windows running when my laptop ran out of power. My suspicion is that macos brought back some subset of resources vscode needs when it restored my state after regaining power, but somehow this left vscode in an inoperable state.
